REASONING: Providing weapons to Taiwan (N) is the most reasonable action, as it directly strengthens their defense capabilities against potential aggression from China. Increasing military capacities (K) follows closely as it enhances U.S. readiness. Sharing intelligence on threats (B) and establishing defense agreements (C) are also critical for bolstering Taiwan's security. Military posturing exercises (H) and deploying surveillance drones (I) send strong signals of support without escalating to conflict. Publicly criticizing China (G) and executing cybersecurity attacks (O) are moderate responses that may deter further aggression but have limited direct impact. Diplomatic actions such as trade agreements (D) and negotiations (F) are less relevant in this critical moment. Cutting diplomatic ties with China (L) or imposing trade restrictions (M) could lead to severe backlash, hence their lower rankings. Full military action (Q, R, S) are last, as they could lead to catastrophic consequences.
